content.definition: A benign vascular tumor of infancy characterized by endothelial cell proliferation. Most common tumor of infancy (4-10% of infants). Appears after birth, proliferates during first year, then slowly involutes over 3-10 years. Distinguished from vascular malformations by natural history and GLUT-1 positivity.

natural_history.precursor_sign: Pale spot, telangiectasia, or bruise-like mark at birth
natural_history.involution: Slow regression 1-10 years, 50% by age 5, 90% by age 9

types: Mixed: combined superficial and deep components
Segmental: dermatomal distribution, higher complication rate
complications: PHACE syndrome (posterior fossa, hemangioma, arterial, cardiac, eye)

management.surgical_excision: Ulcerated, residual fibrofatty tissue after involution

clinical_pearls: Hemangiomas appear AFTER birth, vascular malformations present AT birth
GLUT-1 is pathognomonic for hemangioma (negative in all malformations)
Propranolol revolutionized treatment - rarely need surgery now
PHACE syndrome: large facial hemangioma + CNS/cardiac anomalies
Involuted hemangiomas may leave fibrofatty residuum requiring surgery
